header.title: The Scroll of Set - October 1986
header.category: Esoteric Philosophy, Occult Practice, Organizational News

central_thesis: The Temple of Set's core philosophy centers on individual self-deification through the active process of 'Xeper,' understood as the conscious becoming of oneself as a self-aware god. This is achieved by engaging with fundamental, often 'dark' or 'chaotic' principles of the universe (Khem, Sekhem), distinct from external saviors or organizational dogmas, and contrasting sharply with other occult systems like the O.T.O.'s 'sex magic'. The system provides internal structures (Pylons, Tablets) and philosophical frameworks to support this unique path of individual self-actualization within Western Esotericism.

structure_content.summary: This section provides a cultural and historical context for New Orleans' occult and haunted reputation, suggesting its relevance for a Setian conclave. It details specific locations (museums, cemeteries, haunted houses) known for their association with Voodoo and paranormal activity, offering practical information for attendees.

This article delves into central Setian metaphysical concepts. It defines Khem as the 'secret place of generation' and 'living chaos' embodying active, destructive, and generative fire (Black Flame/Setian Fire) that gestates Xeper. Sekhem is described as Khem's effective, destructive power that annuls abstract principles to create concrete forms and liberates the 'ka' for a new spiritual being. Sekhmet is the personification of Sekhem, representing the disintegrative aspect in the gestation of new beings. The author emphasizes the practical, non-mystical nature of the Left-Hand Path and encourages direct engagement with these principles for III° Initiates.

This section announces the formation of new local Setian groups, or 'Pylons' (Gates of Hell Pylon, Ab Anpu Pylon, Antywey Pylon), within the Temple of Set. Their purpose is to foster community, magical dialogue, and spiritual kinship among geographically dispersed Initiates, facilitating interaction and shared development without strict routine, emphasizing a 'gathering of spiritual beings'.

This article discusses the personal preference for aesthetically intense methods of ionizing ritual chambers over mundane humidifiers. The author expresses a desire to build or acquire equipment like Jacob's Ladders, Tesla coils, or Van de Graaf generators to create a romantic, 'mad doctor' atmosphere for magical work, contrasting with commercially available ionizers.

A short, evocative poem or invocation, serving as a declaration of self-identification and a call to awaken potent forces ('serpent,' 'Jahi,' 'Druj') within the practitioner, embodying a transformative, destructive, and generative power.

This report details the status and purpose of various 'Jeweled Tablets' (Ruby, Onyx, Sapphire, Crystal) within the Temple of Set. These documents are described as an 'encyclopedia of Setian magic and philosophy,' serving as a collection of papers, cross-referenced and loose-leaf for updates. The Ruby Tablet is specifically for II°+ Initiates, functioning as a 'basic reference document' and a set of tools for practitioners to utilize their philosophy and make their own magic, rather than an entertainment device or external validation.

This review offers a critical Setian perspective on Aleister Crowley's O.T.O. and its publication, The Equinox #III-10. It contextualizes the O.T.O.'s history, organizational structure (Masonic model, 'sex magic' as its 'hidden secret'), and philosophical divergences from Crowley's A.'.A.'. The author critiques O.T.O.'s sex magic as a 'Lesser Black Magical device for getting laid' and 'preposterous' for Greater Black Magic, contrasting it with the Setian focus on individual will and self-deification, and highlighting the Temple of Set's stance on other occult organizations.

structure_content.chapter_title: [11] O.K., Let's Make Some Heads and Tails ...
structure_content.summary: A philosophical letter discussing core Setian concepts. It establishes that human life is 'distasteful' because we can conceptualize 'something better,' which proves the existence of Set. It emphasizes the Setian's unique position of self-godhood, free from external saviors or validation. The magician's ability to create and navigate 'subjective universes' (SUs) is highlighted as central to escaping the mundane 'objective universe' (OU). It also touches upon the Setian degree system, linking the IV° to understanding human tragedy and the V° (Magus) to creating conceptual 'ways out'.

key_concepts.definition: The secret place of generation, the dark and hidden center that hides the Neter or incarnate word until the time for manifestation. It is the living chaos that arises with the incarnation of an active fire (Black Flame), which is destructive or generative. It is the dark chaos that gives birth to light without knowing it, and in the vulgar tongue, it means ignorance. Within the Temple of Set, it is seen as a central focus for the Xeper process and relates to the dialectic process of synthesis.

The effective power of Khem; the power that creates darkness by annulment of two abstract principles from which the concrete proceeds. It is the destructive power from which conception arises, willing the destruction of one form for the conception of another and the appearance of new life. It functions as the liberator of the constituents of the 'ka' to prepare a basis for the 'ba' and the conception of a new spiritual being.

The personification of Sekhem. She is described as the disintegrative aspect of Hathor in the gestation of the new being after death and of Mut in the gestation of earthly creatures. Statues of Sekhmet were traditionally carved from black onyx, symbolically linking to the dark aspects of Khem.
The process of 'active becoming or being,' rather than mystification. Khem is understood as a focus for this process. It represents the Setian path of individual self-creation and evolution.

Interpreted as the 'active fire' of Khem, which can be both destructive and generative. It is considered the 'Graal' within Setian philosophy, representing the unique individual consciousness and driving force.
Defined as a path of 'active becoming or being,' distinctly not one of mystification. It emphasizes individual will and direct action, in contrast to passive mysticism.

The ultimate goal for a Setian, where a self-aware Setian becomes his or her own god by 'justifying' and 'approving' their own conscious existence. It involves embracing the loneliness and self-responsibility inherent in 'tasting godhood,' without external saviors or validation.

A foundational document for Adepts (II°+) of the Temple of Set, described as an 'encyclopedia of Setian magic and philosophy.' It is a collection of papers, cross-referenced and loose-leaf, serving as a 'basic reference document' and a set of tools for Setians to develop their own philosophy and practice of magic.

The magician's ability to create and personally move in and out of a number of 'subjective universes' as 'variations' upon the 'natural/objective one' (OU). This freedom is key to escaping the '3D nitty-gritty' of the OU and is a prerogative of the self-aware Setian.

Critiqued as the 'hidden secret' of the O.T.O., utilizing sexual consummation for magical results. It is labeled as a 'Lesser Black Magical device for getting laid' and 'preposterous' as a means for 'Greater Black Magic,' as it violates the Setian premise of focused will by involving 'the loss of one's self in what the French so aptly term "the little death".'

practical_system.description: The Setian practical system, as described, is primarily one of individual self-actualization and conscious becoming (Xeper) through philosophical understanding and direct engagement with core universal principles rather than prescribed external rituals. It involves the magician's ability to manipulate and move between subjective universes (SUs) and the objective universe (OU). The goal is 'self-godhood,' achieved by 'justifying' one's own conscious existence and embracing individual responsibility. Tools and resources are provided to aid in this internal transformation and understanding of Setian philosophy.
tools: Pylons (local groups for Setian interaction, fostering community and 'magical dialogue')

Ruby Tablet (and other Jeweled Tablets: Onyx, Sapphire, Crystal) as structured documents comprising an 'encyclopedia of Setian magic and philosophy,' serving as tools for knowledge, study, and practical application
Ionizing equipment (Jacob's Ladder, Tesla coil, Van de Graaf generator) for creating specific energetic atmospheres in ritual chambers
rituals: On-site reconnaissance for conclaves (preparatory work for magical gatherings)
Ceremony of ordination to the Priesthood of Set (formal recognition of magical development)
Working of Pylons (local group interactions for 'magical dialogue')
Invocation for self-identification and awakening forces (e.g., 'Jeh')
Ionizing ritual chambers (using Jacob's Ladder, Tesla coil, or Van de Graaf generator to enhance atmosphere and energy during magical work)

relevant_quotes.text: Khem is the secret place of generation, the dark and hidden center that hides the Neter or incarnate word until the time for manifestation.
Khem is the living chaos that arises with the incarnation of an active fire, destructive or generative, such as the fire of lightning or seed.

Sekhem is the power that creates darkness by annulment of two abstract principles from which the concrete proceeds. It is Khem's effective power, the destructive power from which conception arises: The male and female factors would make nothing without this pitiless force that wills the destruction of one form for the conception of another and the appearance of a new life.

Sekhem is the liberator of the constituents of the ka. It is Sekhem that effects the difficult disengagement so as to prepare a basis or form for the ba and the conception of a new spiritual being in the Tuat. The personification of Sekhem is Sekhmet, who is the disintegrative aspect of Hathor in the gestation of the new being after death and of Mut in the gestation of earthly creatures.
The Left-Hand Path is not one of mystification but rather of active becoming or being.

Set is not YHVH with a long nose, who will 'justify' your life by officially 'approving' of it or you. Set merely [!] took an element out of the natural universe and gave it a separate consciousness. You are thus in the position of 'justifying' and 'approving' your own conscious existence - which is what we mean by saying that a self-aware Setian is his or her own god.

The magician's ability to create - and to personally move in and out of a number of subjective universes as 'variations' upon the natural/objective one is what frees him from being worn down by the '3D nitty-gritty' you snarl about. Why should you care if the OU doesn't 'validate' the SUs? That is your prerogative.

Sex magic is what Anton LaVey would call a great scheme for getting laid, since your justification is impressively presented to be 'a great mystical awakening or magical working'. Thus you avoid the tedious business of trying to concoct other 'meaningful' excuses and justifications.

critical_analysis.relevance: This collection of articles from 'The Scroll of Set' in 1986 provides crucial insight into the Temple of Set's foundational philosophical and practical framework during a significant period of its development. It meticulously articulates key Setian concepts such as Khem, Sekhem, Sekhmet, and Xeper, positioning them within a unique Left-Hand Path paradigm. The detailed critique of the O.T.O.'s 'sex magic' serves to sharply delineate Setian principles from other contemporary occult traditions, highlighting the emphasis on individual consciousness and self-deification over group dynamics or physical rituals. The discussion of the 'Jeweled Tablets' further clarifies the internal structure for knowledge dissemination and self-study, making the text a vital historical and practical document for understanding the evolving Setian current.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates and members of the Temple of Set, particularly those at the III° degree and above, for whom the 'Ruby Tablet' is intended. Beyond the internal community, it is highly relevant for academic researchers and practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism seeking a deep, technical understanding of Setian philosophy, its unique terminology, and its distinctions from other magical traditions. Individuals interested in the practical application of conscious self-transformation and the exploration of 'dark' metaphysical principles would also find this text invaluable.
